journal-title-group.journal-title: Surgery for obesity and related diseases : official journal of the American Society for Bariatric Surgery

title-group.article-title: Sleeve gastrectomy leads to weight loss in Magel2 knockout mouse

article-meta.aff: 1 University of Michigan, Department of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI USA
2 University of Cincinnati, Department of Internal Medicine, Cincinnati, OH USA
3 University of Alberta, Department of Medical Genetics, Edmonton, AB Canada

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author and person to whom reprint requests should be addressed: Dr. Darleen Sandoval, University of Michigan, 2800 Plymouth Rd., NCRC Building 26-343N, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2800 USA, Phone: (734) 764-6258, Fax: (734) 232-1223, darleens@med.umich.edu

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder characterized by hyperphagia, obesity, cardiopulmonary diseases, and increased mortality. While successful weight loss improves health in PWS, few treatments cause sustained weight loss in obese patients let alone obese individuals with PWS.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: The present study uses the Magel2 knockout (KO) mouse, an animal model of PWS, to conduct a preclinical study on the efficacy of Sleeve Gastrectomy (SG) in PWS.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We performed sham or SG surgeries in 24-28 week old male Magel2 KO and wild-type littermate control mice (WT) who had been maintained on a high-fat diet for 10 weeks. We monitored body weight, food intake, and fat and lean mass pre- and post-operatively. Fasting glucose, glucose tolerance, and counterregulation were measured post-operatively.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Magel2 KO animals had similar recovery and mortality rates compared to WT. SG resulted in similar weight loss, by specifically loss of fat but not lean mass, in both Magel2 KO and WT mice. SG also resulted in significantly lower fasting glucose levels and a reduction in fat intake in both Magel2 KO and WT mice. We also found that Magel2 KO mice failed to increase their food intake in response to the glucoprivic agent, 2-deoxy-D-glucose (2DG) suggesting impaired glucose counterregulation, but this occurred regardless of surgical status. All results were considered significant when P < 0.05.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We find in this mouse model of PWS, SG is a safe, effective strategy for weight and fat loss.
